cleaned_text: Hepatitis Day, marked globally on July 28, doctors across the state are stressing the urgent need to increase vaccination and improve the detection of cases. The theme this year is 'One Life, One [Liver](https://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/topic/liver) '. Hepatitis is a general term used to describe inflammation of the liver caused by several viruses (viral hepatitis), chemicals, drugs, alcohol or certain genetic disorders. As per the National Viral Hepatitis Control Program (NVHCP), in India, an estimated 40 million people suffer from Hepatitis B, and 6 to 12 million people suffer from Hepatitis C. As per the state health department, from 2019 to June 2023, a total of 2,138 [Hepatitis B](https://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/topic/hepatitis-b) patients underwent treatment, whereas out of the 1,230 Hepatitis C patients reported in the state, 1,158 have completed their treatment. Dr Manoj Dongre, a consultant liver transplant surgeon at DPU Private Super Specialty Hospital in Pimpri, said, "Reasons such as unhealthy lifestyle can lead to inflammatory damage to the liver." Dr Bipin Vibhute, head of the Liver and Multi-organ Transplant Department at Sahyadri Hospitals, said, "Recent ground-breaking antiviral drugs have demonstrated remarkable efficacy, bringing higher cure rates and shorter treatment durations. It ensures better outcomes and minimal side effects." Dr Mahendra Kendre, coordinator of NVHCP with the state health department, said, "All pregnant women should test for Hepatitis B and receive an HBIG injection if positive. This will avoid mother-to-child transmission. Under the NVHCP programme, we have injected about 2,200 kids from 2019 to June 2023" As per data from the Regional cum State Organ and Tissue Transplant Organisation (ROTTO -SOTTO), a total of 89 livers were transplanted in 2022. In 2021, this number stood at 88, and in 2020, the number was 69. "Less than 10% of patients who need a transplant receive the organ. We should focus on preventing its need," Dr Akash Shukla, director of hepatology at Sir HN Reliance Hospital, said. Dr Pratik Tibdewal, consultant gastroenterologist at Wockhardt Hospitals in Mumbai said, "In addition to unsafe sex, Hepatitis can be transmitted through infected blood or body fluids, sharing needles or razors, contaminated food and water and blood transfusion."
